In "The Sign of Four," there is a scene where the word "RACHE" (German for "revenge") is written in blood on the wall, which serves as a clue to the identity of the murderer. While this is not the same as using a seemingly innocuous object to send a threatening message, it does involve the use of a symbol or sign that appears to be innocuous at first but actually holds a sinister meaning.

The use of symbols and signs to convey hidden meanings or to add an element of mystery and intrigue is a common device in detective fiction, and it is one that Conan Doyle used frequently in the Sherlock Holmes stories. In "The Sign of Four," the use of the word "RACHE" is a clever plot device that adds to the suspense and the sense of danger that pervades the story.

Overall, "The Sign of Four" is a classic example of the detective genre, with a complex and engaging plot, a cast of memorable characters, and plenty of twists and turns to keep the reader guessing until the very end.
